78C EXT AMERICAN RIVER PROSPECTORS TRAIL DAY

21A INT PIONEER TOWN 02 TRADING POST DAY

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLOUNT RANCH NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gunfire lights up the room. Two guns fire back. A silhoue collapses. Silence and darkness. Eli scratches a match and lights tw lamps. He hands one to Charlie. They walk around the room stepping over corpses. Four of them.  2. Lamp light on the corpses’ faces. One man is still breath Charlie sits him up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s Blount? Blood froths on the man’s lips. Charlie shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Blount? The man coughs. Charlie finishes him off. Something on the ceiling catches Eli’s attention: dust trickling from between the planks.

dialogues.speaker: INT BLOUNT RANCH ATTIC NIGHT
dialogues.text: Up in the attic, dry and dark. A scared man cowers behind bales of hay. Blount. His hands scratch at the wooden slats of the roof, rippin away straw and adobe. He hears footsteps on the steps of the ladder. He groans. In the hole of the roof, a chunk of sky appear the moon... Footsteps on the attic floor. Blount slips through the opening...

dialogues.speaker: EXT RANCH ROOF-NIGHT
dialogues.text: --- rolls, falls from the roof... ... lies on the ground, the wind knocked out of him... He sits up...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Blount? Blount turns around. Charlie barely aims. Shoots. Blount collapses. Charlie shoots twice to finish him off, then turns to the ranch and reloads.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Charlie! Charlie!  Suddenly: Eli’s voice is heard from above. Charlie steps away. He looks up and sees his brother in the hole in the roof, pointing to something.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The barn! He hears something galloping behind him. He turns around, clutching his gun. A horse on fire gallops through the landscape. 5A EXT BARN BLOUNT’S RANCH-NIGHT: The barn is on fire. Through the flames, we see the silhouettes of horses panicking. Shielding their faces, the two brothers try to penetrate inferno.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I’m not walking home !

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Eli ! Don’t be fucking stupid, let's go ! They’re just fucking horses ! On his last try, Eli comes running back out with his coat fire. He rolls around on the ground to put out the flames Charlie helps him. Helpless, they hear their horses neigh in terror. 5B EXT BARN. BLOUNT FARM-NIGHT. In the background, the barn is still burning.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How many you think we've killed?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, six, seven?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Well, we fucked that up real good. They disappear into the night.  6A EXT COMMODORE’S MANSION-DAY: It is gray and cold. Hard to tell if it is dawn or dusk. The dark silhouette of a huge Neo-Gothic building. On the gate, a sign with the owner’s coat of arms: a sun shining a globe, stamped with an anchor. It is the Commodore’s mansion. On the other side of the white fence, Eli Sisters is wait on a low-backed horse, slumped like a sagging sofa - “Tub Eli is dressed sloppily, his stomach protrudes over his b He looks at the horse attached beside him: a superb Spani Barb horse, large and muscled - “Nimble”. He shakes his h in disbelief. He looks back at the manor house. A silhouette appears at first floor window. It is his brother Charlie, in the glo oil-burning lamps. Then another silhouette appears beside him, a smaller, wh haired man, dressed in black: the Commodore. 6B EXT. COMMODORE’S MANSION-DAY : Charlie is coming back. He looks dirty and sloppy too, bu thin and naturally elegant.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What did the Commodore say? Did you mention the horses?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let's go get a drink. Eli tries to catch up with his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers are sitting in the back of a saloon. Not man customers at the bar. Charlie is drinking brandy. Eli is drinking less. Charlie speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He said if there’d been a lead man, we wouldn’t have had problems at the Blount ranch. He says for the next job, we need to have a lead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s it mean about money?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: More for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No. My money, I mean. Same as before?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, no. Less, obviously. Eli makes a face. Charlie pours him a glass to keep him c

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The Commodore wants to pay for a lead man, that’s fine. But it’s bad business to short the man underneath.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're not asking what the job is?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you anyways. We have to go South and find Morris.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The Commodore’s John Morris? ..-And why do we have to find this Morris? Charlie downs his glass, he leans over to Eli.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s after a prospector named Hermann Kermit Warm.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Great. He can find him and kill him. End of story.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Morris is a scout, not a killer. The mission is: Morris finds Warm, he holds him, we come in and finish the job. That’s the mission. Eli thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the horses?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s your goddamn problem with the horses?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The Commodore told us he would get us new horses!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that what he did?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No. For you he got a new horse. For me, he made room in his stable and got rid of some horse meat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you think we can talk about this later?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, I don’t need the horse later, I need it now, for the job! The bartender comes to take the bottle and get paid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The horse is fine, stop being a baby.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Is it the words “go halves” that you don’t like? To the bartender, seeing that Charlie isn’t budging.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The lead’s man paying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross the street to their horses. We discover the town: a prosperous, thriving western city

dialogues.speaker: EXT SISTERS HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: In a prairie, a small log cabin. Their horses are tied in front

dialogues.speaker: INT SISTERS HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: The inside is rudimentary. Each brother is in what serves his room, packing for the trip. Charlie’s room looks like sty, Eli’s is clean and tidy. On one of the “living room” walls is a framed landscape c out of a newspaper. Charlie shifts the frame to uncover a hiding place. He gropes inside and pulls out a few bills, then a few gold pieces. He counts them and places them in large wallet. ool se Eli cuts his hair in front of a dusty mirror. His long ha falls on the ground strand by strand. He calls for Charli help.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hey, come cut the back of this for me. Just cut it off. Charlie smiles at Eli’s face in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You look funny like that. woe] oe Eli takes a red woolen shawl from the dresser drawer and folds it with particular care.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SISTERS HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Eli mounts Tub, who seems to buck under his weight. He digs his spurs in the horse’s flank, the horse balks.. joins Charlie. The two men leave the log cabin and prairie behind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RELAY STATION 1 DAY
dialogues.text: A relay station, further south.  8. Sitting at a small table in the shade of the verandah, a is writing a letter. His clothes are elegant and understa He is well groomed, fine-featured and strong. A handsome John Morris, 35.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear solicitor, my friend, My father had vowed to do two things. First, to do whatever it takes to ruin my life. And second, to disinherit me. He kept his word for the first. Not for the second. It surprises me, and I attribute it to his declining health. In any case, I want nothing of this inheritance: not the titles, the factory, the buildings or the Westwood property... I want nothing. I’l1l be back in Washington before winter. We will deal with all these details then. I shake your hand. Your friend, John Morris. Across from him, the landscape pulses under the sun. John folds his letter.

dialogues.speaker: 12_INT/EXT RELAY STATION 1 DAY
dialogues.text: The letter disappears into a big leather sack marked “Mai

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: When did the last wagon train pass through?

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a guy named Warm. Hermann Kermit Warm, 5 foot 6, lean, dark skin, no bags or gear. He’s traveling in a wagon train. The owner did not see Warm.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RELAY STATION 1 DAY
dialogues.text: John Morris heads back to his curly horse, built to ride and hard. They head down the trail. The mare immediately launches into a perfect half-gallop.  9. Torso straight, feet in the stirrups, John Morris rides o like a Mongol horseman.

dialogues.speaker: EXT OREGON COUNTRYSIDE DAY
dialogues.text: Tall grass blowing in the wind. On their horses, side by side, the brothers slowly cross large, sloping landscape.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Gorgeous country, isn’t it? Odd we haven’t seen anyone since this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: If we’d stayed on the trail, we'd have come across more people.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s nothing like what they say. Supposedly the whole world is searching for gold! Honestly...

dialogues.speaker: 15A EXT COUNTRYSIDE CAMP SISTERS 1 NIGHT
dialogues.text: They set up camp and finish eating by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What did this Hermann Warm do?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He stole something from the Commodore. Eli thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Don’t you find it strange, all these men foolish enough to steal from such a dangerous man? Charlie has no opinion.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How do they even steal anything at all? We know how cautious the Commodore is.  10.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Caution has nothing to do with it. He does business in every corner of the country, and even overseas. A man can’t be everywhere at once. It stands to reason he’d be victimized.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Victimized?!?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, victimized.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The Commodore is «victimized»?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What would you call it? If a man is forced to protect his fortune with the likes of us?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Not “victimized”...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're not going to start nitpicking over every word. What’s your problem? Are you upset?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re upset that I’m the lead man? Is that it? If that’s it,just say so. But stop splitting hairs...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I’m not splitting hairs! You’re using a strange word and I’m making you take notice... Charlie drops his tin pan and goes to his corner to sprea open his blanket. According to a well-established routine, Eli collects the pans and silverware, and then stokes the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli spreads out a first blanket, then lays a patchwork qu on top. He winds his pocket watch, puts it next to his “pillow” and lies down.  11. Nearby, Charlie lets out a loud fart. Eli checks his watch and moves the big hand up to the 9.

dialogues.speaker: 15C_ EXT MOUNTAIN RIDGE DAY
dialogues.text: They climb up a steep path, spurring the horses on. They at the top and let the horses catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ccould it be Miss Emilia Patridge?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s the schoolteacher who gave you that silly red scarf... (imitating him) The one you keep folding and unfolding in secret?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It’s called a shawl. Am I not entitled to any privacy?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Have you made plans with this Miss Emilia?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Plans?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To marry her, start a family, have children... something like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why are you so interested all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was wondering about family. You remember how Pa was with Ma?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes, Charlie, I remember.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Makes you think... You’re not scared to reproduce yourself?  12.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You do realize that our father was stark-raving mad and that we got his foul blood in our veins?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Our father drank, Charlie. Charlie looks at him seriously, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That was his gift to us. That blood. That’s why we’re good at what we do. 16 EXT HILL WARM’S CARAVAN POV DAY:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: POV from a pair of binoculars: a caravan of three covered wagons struggles up a hill. We see the drivers whip their horses. The passengers get and push. The binoculars remain on the wagons and men. When they have reached the top of the hill, the passenger climb back into the wagons. The binoculars stop on the wagon bringing up the rear, an the man who just sat against the rear slat: Hermann Kermit Warm. 16B EXT HILL WARM’S CARAVAN DAY: John Morris puts away his binoculars. He starts off, at a distance from the caravan.

dialogues.speaker: 17_EXT PIONEER TOWN DAY
dialogues.text: From the saloon door, Morris watches a house being built. Warm is one of the workmen. He watches him saw planks, assemble beams and direct the maneuver to hoist the facad  13.

dialogues.speaker: INT/ EXT. FRONTIER TOWN DAY
dialogues.text: At the end of the day, Morris sees the owner of the house hand Warm some coins for his labor.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: May 15th. Myrtle Creek, Oregon. The gold rush has made the detective’s job much easier. When you look for a woman, a man, a horse or a dog, just follow the gold. And soon enough you'll find whom or what you’re after. Hermann Kermit Warm, eats messily, 5 foot 6, lean, dark skin, no friends, no baggage, no money.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. PIONEER TOWN 01/ TENT CAMP DAY
dialogues.text: Morris sees Warm back in the encampment, where he pays a of soup, and lies for down on a cot. He pulls up the cover over his head and lies still.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PIONEER TOWN 01 DAWN
dialogues.text: A wagon train is about to depart. Hermann Kermit Warm cli aboard the last wagon. At the village outskirts, Morris waits for the caravan to disappear before setting off on his own.

dialogues.speaker: 21A INT PIONEER TOWN 02 TRADING POST DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie and Eli are covered in sweat and dust.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sisters. S-I-S-T-E-R-S, like sisters. Behind the counter, a storekeeper in an undershirt and an apron tenses up when he hears their name. He stops looking through the mail left there to be picked

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: No, nothing. I’d have remembered.  14.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No news is good news. What’s the next town on the trail?

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: Myrtle Creek.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: Two days.

dialogues.speaker: 21B INT PIONEER TOWN 02 TRADING POST DAY
dialogues.text: Eli walks around the store. Every possible accoutrement f prospecting: pans, cradles, buckets, pickaxes, a dismantl model of Long Tom, oil lamps, clothing made of fabric, of leather... The store is dark and luminous at the same tim is enthralled, curious... He stops in front of a small metal box. Inside, a small b with a wooden handle. He picks it up and studies it. The storekeeper comes by.

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: Interested?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: A toothbrush, sir. To keep your teeth longer and your breath fresher. Look. He opens a box of tooth powder and shoves it under his no He sniffs. Smells good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What kind of boots do you have?

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: I'll be with you right away, sir!

dialogues.speaker: EXT PIONEER TOWN 02 SALOON STREET EVENING
dialogues.text: A small town, but lively. The brothers walk down Main Str Eli is carrying his small package from the store.  15. Charlie is freshly outfitted from head to toe. You can al hear his clothes crinkling.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You know, when we stop, that’s the kind of store I’d like to have.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: When we stop what?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Killing people! I believe I could settle into a life like that. Didn't it seem pleasant in there?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'd die of boredom.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It seemed peaceful enough to me. I bet that man sleeps very well at night.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because that’s the point? To sleep well at night? You don’t sleep well at night?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, and neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me? You must be kidding. I sleep like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Says you! You grit your teeth, and sometimes you cry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I cry?!?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes, you cry. Charlie stares at him, smirks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Are you trying to tell me something?  16.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: We're talking... I’m just telling you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. (he hands his saddlebags to his brother) Put this in the room. We’1ll meet up later. Eli crosses the street loaded down and heads for the salo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naive black and white drawings illustrating how to use th toothbrush. A small hotel room. Eli brushes his teeth according to the instructions. He i diligent and excessive, as if inventing a style. He sits in front of the window overlooking the street and entrance to the saloon. Eli blows into his cupped hands to smell his new breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night has fallen. Eli is in the street. He finishes eating something, all the while looking out t corner of his eye at the saloon. Inside, Charlie is in the middle of a conversation with a in a suit and hat. They have both been drinking. Charlie admires the revolver hanging from his belt. The man hands to him. Charlie weighs it in his hand. He likes its proportions. When he hands it back, his mouth is smiling, not his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli wanders through the tents at the town limits. There a people in all kinds of attire, speaking all kinds of languages, guttural and crystalline.  17. He notices Russian astrakhan hats and the strange pointy of Shtetl Jews. Leaning over a cauldron, a woman sells soup for a few cen She serves him a bowl. He eats.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It’s good. Is it vegetables?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Bortsch.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I taste dill.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Bortsch ! The woman does not understand. He gives up. He hears chanting from behind. He approaches. Finishing h soup, he watches a family observe the Sabbath ritual.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT HOTEL ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Eli is asleep. Shouts, gunshots coming from the street wa him up. He grabs his gun and runs to the window. Down below, in the middle of the street, Charlie is teete with a gun in each hand. He shoots into the air.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Five... Six... are you counting? Seven, eight... Nine! Oh where did you go? Where did you go ? The saloon and the street empty. Silhouettes cautiously h the facades. The street is now deserted.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You fucking cowards... No one wants to measure themselves up against Charlie Sisters?! No one really? Eli goes back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Go home you fools...  18.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The noise is coming closer. When the door opens, Eli turn the wall and shuts his eyes. The room now echoes with Charlie’s heavy breathing and groans.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +. And that idiot, fast asleep... What good are you?... Damn, if you weren’t my brother, I'd have ditched you ages ago... Even the Commodore wanted to ... “Why do you carry around that dead weight?”... “Because he’s my brother, I answered. We all have our fucking crosses to bear!"”... He appreciated how loyal I am. “Faith will be repaid with faith,” he said. A beat. Then suddenly, right next to Eli’s ear, the click a revolver being cocked. Eli opens his eyes and looks at brother. Above him, Charlie’s revolver is aimed at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -.. Tst-tst... It’s not nice to fake it.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question, brother? Who can have faith in you? Real faith? Huh? He lifts his hand sententiously and stumbles off to bed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WILLAMETTE VALLEY DAY
dialogues.text: They are riding their horses across the Willamette Valley Eli is sullen. Charlie is riding behind, slumped over Nimble’s neck. All of a sudden, Eli hears a big thump. Ja he stops Tub... He dismounts and steps toward Charlie, lying on the groun He lifts him up, not gently. His new outfit is now dirty. Charlie feels nauseous.Eli turns around. He hears Charlie vomit. Eli grabs him roughly and helps him back into the saddle.  19.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t judge me, please. Some days we're stronger than others.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WILLAMETTE VALLEY DAY
dialogues.text: They are riding one behind the other. Eli remains silent. Charlie is feeling a bit better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You okay? Charlie catches up to ELi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you pouting? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is it because I drank? Eli feels Charlie staring at him. He stops Tub.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Listen, either ride in front or ride in back, but I don’t feel like talking.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just like I said: you’re pouting. You’re ruining the atmosphere on purpose. We could have had a delightful day and you took it on yourself to ruin it... Oh, fuck it. Pout if you want to. He spurs Nimble and takes the lead.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, if you insist on pouting, you should give it your all. Give us a full pout, Eli. You must stew and hate and revisit all the slights I offered you in childhood. Don’t you forget a single one! Eli smiles slightly.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, you mustn’t smile when pouting! It’s wrong and you know it’s wrong!

dialogues.speaker: EXT PIONEER CITY 03 DAY
dialogues.text: Heavy fog. Another pioneer town on the trail. As usual, t is one main street, wood houses and store signs. John Morris shakily crosses the muddy street on wooden pl that have been laid down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morris is having dinner at a table in the back. Without having to look up from his notebook, he feels Warm’s pres at the bar. Dirty, muddy, haggard.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: May 17th, Wolf Creek. I travel through places that didn’t exist 3 months ago. First there are tents, then houses, then 2 months later shops with women fiercely discussing the price of flour. I found this line by Thoreau. “This town too lies out”... At one point, he senses Warm’s shadow by his side.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: We've seen each other before?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: No I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You were in Myrtle Creek two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes I was, like many other folk.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Are you heading down to San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: No, just to Jacksonville.  21.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Work?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, work. Warm is now sitting two tables away.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: And you, San Francisco? Gold?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Yes, like many other folk. A beat. Warm looks at him with a strange smile. Morris is almost embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: May I tell you something, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Typically, when a man wishes another man good day, he smiles while facing the other person, but once he passes by, the smiles drops from his face. Not you. Your smile remains on your lips after you have turned away. Warm’s candor and good nature throw Morris for a loop.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (embarassed) Well I... I’ve hadn’t noticed... It’s common courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: It’s not only that. You take a genuine pleasure in communing with others. Am I mistaken?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I honestly do not know. (a beat) Would you like to join me for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: I'd have loved to, but I am a bit hard up at the moment.  22.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: As my guest, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are having dinner. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: And what takes you to Jacksonville?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Business to settle. I’m meeting two of my associates there.How are you making your way south?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: I have a seat in a covered wagon.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: How long do you think till you reach Frisco?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: The question is not how long before I get there, the question is what state will I be in when I do. If I do. To be honest with you, my faith in my hosts is very limited. They've rifled through my belongings several times and every time I take out my money, their eyes are like daggers.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Mr Warm. You ought to not endanger yourself in that way. You have to be more careful than that

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: What other choice do I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corral. Horses, mules and oxen. The horse dealer shows Warm some mules. Morris examines t

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: 50, horseshoes included.  23.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: 35 is for a mule!

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: 40, with the saddle, bag and shoes.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: Hey listen to me if you want to by a horse you pay the price for a horse. Morris examines the mare’s hooves.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You're never gonna sell this horse. Not at 50, not at 40... She’s a bad hip, anyone’d see that with an eye. 40! 40.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen I have found him. I have managed to make an acquaintance and have arranged to travel with him. If all goes well we should be in Jacksonville...

dialogues.speaker: 33_EXT PIONEER TOWN 03 TRAIL DAWN
dialogues.text: Morris and Warm are riding side by side, chatting. They l the slow covered wagons behind.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: win seven days... I will try to hold him until your arrival and find a secluded place to hand him over.

dialogues.speaker: INT RELAY STATION 2 DAY
dialogues.text: A relay station on the trail, for horses and stagecoaches Eli finishes reading the message from Morris:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: «Make haste. John Morris.»  24.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: One good point for Morris, even if I don’t like the... “Make haste.” Who does that asshole think he is? He turns to the horse-dealer in charge of the place.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: When did they pass through?

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: Four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is there a faster way to Jacksonville, off trail?

dialogues.speaker: HORSE DEALER
dialogues.text: Well, it’s rougher to go up the mountains but you’ll save a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST MOUNTAIN ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: They climb switchbacks up a mountain road. A forest looms before them, like a dark green wall. Their silhouettes disappear behind the line of trees.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP SISTERS 2 NIGHT
dialogues.text: Eli is woken by groaning. He turns toward Charlie. He sta up and leans over him. Tears are flowing from Charlie’s closed eyes. He whimpers groans in his sleep. Eli feels moved by his brother’s pain. He wavers, then pu out his hand to wake him. Charlie’s eyes suddenly pop ope

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Peek-a-boo ! Eli jumps up. Charlie bursts out laughing. He clutches his stomach. Eli looks peeved. Charlie imitat Eli.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Fool!  25.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to kiss me! The blankets shake as they laugh uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: 37_EXT FOREST/BURN WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: They ride, tiny among the tall trees. Their voices and hoofbeats echo among the trunks. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The rain muddied it all up. I can’t see a thing. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: We must be able to pick up the trail somewhere. They split up. Eli rides alone, looking for the trail. He turns back fro time to time, but no longer sees his brother. He is overtaken by a feeling of dread. He spots some ruts, some hoof prints... He whistles:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Over here ! He continues onward and finds the remains of a wagon, an animal carcass... and human bones. He dismounts. The wagon has obviously been plundered. He kicks at some pathetic scraps. A piece of paper catches h eye. He unfolds it, wipes it clean and tries to make out writing. He hears Charlie arrive. He slips the paper into jacket and gets back on Tub.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/INDIANS. DAY
dialogues.text: They are riding, Charlie in front, Eli behind deciphers t letter he found among the debris.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (OFF)
dialogues.text: “Dear Mother, I feel lonely and the days are long here. My horse has passed and he was a close friend. I think of your cooking and wonder what I’m doing here. I believe I will come home soon. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (OFF)
dialogues.text: I have almost 200 dollars in gold dust. It’s not the pile I'd hoped for, but good enough for now. The smell of smoke in still my nostrils and I haven’t had a laughed in such a long time. Mother! I think I will leave here very soon. With all my love, Your son”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoldering embers in the fire. Eli is asleep, wrapped in his patchwork quilt. He half- o his eyes and sees his brother by the light of the embers, gun across his lap. A fine watchman. He shuts his eyes, feeling reassured. Close on black. Open on extreme CU: A hairy spider climbs up Eli’s neck. reaches his neck. It remains there for a beat, as if to g its bearings. When Eli’s mouth opens, it disappears insid Close on black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A starry sky. Morris walks up to the horses. Behind him, a few dozen fe away, there’s another campfire with a few prospectors hav dinner. Morris opens Warm’s small bag and discovers some clothes, uninteresting artefacts, a conversion table, a slide rule chemistry handbook and a few notebooks with “This noteboo belongs to H.K. Warm” written on the cover. He opens of those: pages filled with calculations and formulas. He hears footsteps behind him and goes back near the fire Warm comes up, he’s holding some bowls and cups of coffee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are eating.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’ve only just noticed that’s the only bag you have? I guess you’re gonna have to buy gear when you get to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: I don’t need equipment.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You're going to look for gold ina river without a shovel, a pail, a cradle...

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: This is the great challenge all prospectors face. How do I get what’s just beneath my feet? There’s only two solutions of course: hard labour and good luck. I’ve been working on a third solution for many years. One that is simpler, faster, more certain. And I think today I found it. Morris stares in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: No offence, Warm, frankly I’m having a hard time.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You know it’s funny, people usually don't believe me, and then when they do, they want to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: What is this idea? Morris looks at him. Warm smiles. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Well I told you I’m a chemist. It’s the idea of a chemist, it’s a formula.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: “Abracadabra”?  28.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: No, a divining substance.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: A divining substance you... you mix in the river water? Warm nods.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: This formula... this diviner... call it what you may... as a man of science, have you ever tested it?

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST CAMP SISTERS 3 DAY
dialogues.text: The sun has trouble piercing through forest and mist. Charlie is on his feet. Next to him, Eli’s blanket doesn' move. He gives his brother a kick.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Eli wake up !

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I don’t feel good... Charlie lifts up the blanket. Eli is hunched up, shiverin His head has swollen to twice its size. It is a different color.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh shit what happened to your face? Eli answers inaudibly.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s all swollen and your neck! You look like... one of those dogs, what is it, the... The Mastiff!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Fuck you! I’m sick.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All right sit up. Let me look at you. Eli opens his mouth. Charlie looks inside and makes a fac  29.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Got a gallon of blood sloshing around in there! Charlie helps him sit up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You think you can sit in a saddle?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I’m freezing. Eli’s head bobs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST EVENING
dialogues.text: Pouring rain. An occasional flash of lightning lights up tree trunks. Charlie leads them on. Eli holds on, rocked and forth. Semi-unconscious, Eli hunches over Tub’s neck. The horse trips. Eli’s teeth clatter and he shouts in pain. Bloody trickles onto Tub’s neck. Charlie hands him a wad of tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stick this between your teeth. It’ll stop them from chattering. We're going to have to hurry if we want to outrun the storm. He takes the reins of Eli’s horse.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You holding on? Eli grabs onto the saddle knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie struggles to open an oilcloth, like a sail slappi in the wind. He stretches it between two trees then unfolds another on underneath... He lays Eli down on it and covers him with blankets. Eli shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m tired, Charlie... He closes his eyes. Black.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NIGHTMARE/ FOREST. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wind roars, rain patters. Open. Eli’s low-angle POV: In a sudden flash of lightning, shadow of a man’s face cuts out in the light of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: There you are my sweeties.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Pa... Pa...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I’ve looked all over for you. The silhouette’s man chopping wood with an axe. We move in slowly, we hear choked breathing.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Pa?!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Come closer, let me take you in my arms.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (OFF)
dialogues.text: No... No! 30. the We come nearer and find arms and legs on the chopping blo and his feet red with blood. Black.

dialogues.speaker: 42C EXT FOREST CAMP SISTERS 4 NIGHT
dialogues.text: Eli opens his eyes. He takes a moment to observe the trees: they slowly sway, water drips from their leaves, they straighten up. His he looks less swollen. He sticks a finger in his mouth, retches and spits out bl phlegm.  31.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You okay? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I think so. Charlie, naked, squats next to a dying fire, trying to wa up some beans. His clothes are stretched out around the f Eli comes to. A huge brown clump between their camp and t horses catches his eye: the corpse of a grizzly bear. He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, this gentleman wandered into the camp last night. Eli goes over to look at the grizzly’s cadaver in the mud

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He got your horse real good. He went right for him. Eli goes over to Tub, still shaking: The bear ripped away some of his nose. A damaged left eye under a bloody lid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s the horses that woke me up. What a fucking night!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I had a dream about Pa’ last night. Charlie throws away the beans, stands up and gathers up h clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well that’s perfect ! I'm sick of this place. It reeks of death, everything is fucking soaked. Let’s go! 43 INT JACKSONVILLE MORRI’S ROOM DAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morris washes his hands and face at the basin.  32. He dries himself off and surprises his reflection in the mirror. He looks at himself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: In front of the Motel, Morris asks a man for directions. TITLE: JACKSONVILLE OREGON.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Third house, on the right.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morris takes a walk around. Once he gets away from the trail, things become quiet. He checks out passersby as if counting them. On the outskirts of town, behind a sort of hangar, he spo shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes open the door: hay, not much light. Through the wood slats in the wall, the town, far enough away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morris opens the door to his room. 47 INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM DAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His saddle bags and knapsack are still on the floor. He p his knapsack on the bed, opens it...

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Shit... He goes to the window and peers into the street. No one. heads to the door and opens it: Warm is on the landing, a pair of handcuffs dangling from hand and, in the other, a Colt aimed at Morris’s forehead  33.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Are you looking for this? Get back... Get back! He points to Morris and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Are you not going to say “listen Hermann I can explain”? Huh? Warm throws the handcuff on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Pick that up, face that way, put it on your left hand. Morris obeys. The handcuff closes around his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Let me see your hand... Good, now the other one. Morris puts his hand behind his back. Just as Warm is abo to cuff him, he pulls out his left hand, spins around and punches him in the face. Warm goes flying backwards. The falls to the floor. Morris grabs it. When Warm tries to get up, Morris pistol-whips him. 48A INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM NIGHT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night has fallen. Warm is sitting bound and gagged on a chair. Morris is ly on the bed with his gun at his side. Blood rolls down Warm’s head. He moans. He moans harder. Morris understands and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (pointing to the gag) If I take it off, will you keep quiet? Warm nods. Morris removes the gag. Warm breathes. He look dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Are we waiting for your friends? No answer.  34.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: How could you be so two-faced? What taught you such duplicity? Is it greed? I hadn’t noticed that in you... I really hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You keep quiet or I’1l put this back in.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You think they’11l kill me? They won’t kill me... Not right away. A beat. He looks at Morris.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: What do you think your Commodore wants? He’s the one who tried to rob me in Oregon City. He’s after my Formula, my invention.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: So your friends... Your friends are on their way here to torture me. To torture me, did you know that? Morris didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: They’1l cut off my fingers, burn my feet, gouge out my eyes... They’1l torture me till I talk.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Morris, can I ask you something? ...Are you gonna watch? ...Are you gonna write it down in your book of adventures? Morris looks at him now.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Warm... I... He searches for the words, but cannot find them.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: It’s this world... It’s an abomination.  35. Warm’s face is now turned toward the window. He doesn’t a anything.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: He stopped talking, didn’t say another word. He watched the sun rise through the window. 48B INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM DAWN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is up. Warm his waking up. He notices his hands are free, the handcuffs are gone. He gets up and walks closer to Morris who’s sleeping on t bed. He pushes him gently. Morris wakes up with a start, in his hand. He sees Warm standing before him and lowers his gun. Morr slowly emerges. They look at each other for a moment, then, as he straigh up:

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You don’t think you’re making a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie on Nimble, at breakneck speed. Eli and Tub behind. Tub is galloping with his damaged hea down at his side, as if drowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hilltop. A town below. Eli looks down at the town. Sitting behind him, Charlie h laid out a rag. He is cleaning and preparing his weapons assiduously.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How do we go about this Warm?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like we usually do.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Well usually there’s no Morris

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Morris hands over Warm. We go some place quiet and finish the job. You done? Eli nods. Charlie stands up and gathers his effects.

dialogues.speaker: 51A EXT JACKSONVILLE DAY
dialogues.text: We recognize Main Street Jacksonville and Smith’s hotel.. where Warm and Morris stayed. Eli and Charlie approach the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You go round back.

dialogues.speaker: 51B EXT JACKSONVILLE DAY
dialogues.text: Eli gets off his horse and looks around behind the hotel: windows, gallery, roof... All of a sudden, a noise: Someone is trying to open an upstairs window. Eli takes out his gun. He is about to sh when Charlie's head pops out...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Christ, Charlie, I almost shot! Eli unlocks his gun. Charlie pops his head back out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They’re not here!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They left, four days ago! Morris left a note. Shit!

dialogues.speaker: INT SALOON JACKSONVILLE DAY
dialogues.text: They are in a saloon amid other customers. They both drin while Charlie reads Morris’letter out loud:  37.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: “Dear gentlemen, I’m sorry to inform you that Hermann Kermit Warm has made a precipitate departure. He must have hopped a wagon train and left town. I am going after him as of today. Good luck. Sincerely. John Morris”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Hermann Kermit Warm has made a precipitate departure”?!? Who the fuck is he kidding? Who the fuck is this pretentious asshole kidding?!? He grabs the letter and crumples it. He flings it to the floor and tramples it.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What now? Charlie finishes his glass and pours himself another.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We keep on. We said between Jacksonville and Mayfield, and we're only in Jacksonville. And God damn it, the job isn’t “Jacksonville” or “Mayfield”, the job is to kill Warm!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (pointing to the barman) Say it louder, I don’t think he heard.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (softer) Wherever the fuck Warm is, Mayfield or wherever, we go there and get it over with!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: When will we be back home?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Once we’re done with the job, Eli. Eli picks up the letter and uncrumples it.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I get the feeling they’re farther and farther ahead of us. How long were we in that forest?  38.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your spells and illnesses haven’t saved us any time, that’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What do you mean, that it’s my fault?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little. Isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You want to talk about your constant drunkenness? Didn’t it cost us any time? Charlie finishes his glass, slams a coin on the bar and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Days when you can’t even sit up in the saddle straight?? The other morning when you puked on yourself?... My spells! My ass! Eli follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BEFORE MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Warm and Morris ride side by side, speaking like friends.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: What we need to do is to put an end to all this barbarity. Put an end to all this violence, find a solution for it. By inventing a new society. A society...

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP WARM/MORRIS 2 NIGHT
dialogues.text: Warm and Morris each sit to one side of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: «+. where the relationships among men is governed by respect and the absence of profit. Thus a society without greed. Do you agree?  39.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: What’s it have to do with your formula? You're looking for gold too, like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: For me the gold is just a stepping- stone. John I’m serious. To found a new society. One, one that will consecrate itself not to profit or gold, but its, its spiritual development, its own subsistence, nothing more, the education of its children...

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: And where do you intend to create this society?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Dallas, northern Texas. There are already many people waiting there. More are on the way from Europe. Warm take a sip. Morris remains silent. Troubled. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Well I can see I’ve lost you... John?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: One evening, you told me about your father that you left him because there was no place for you. As for me all I can say is that I left my family out of hatred and that my father was the person I despised most in this world I...despised everything about him. I sincerely thought I had been freed of all that until tonight, listening to you, what do I realize? That most of the things that I thought I’d been doing, these past years, freely, the opinions that I thought I had of my own volition, were in fact dictated by my hatred towards that man.  40.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I'm 35 years old and my life is like an empty cylinder. Black.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RELAY STATION 3 DAY
dialogues.text: Further south, in a relay station. Morris is writing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (OFF)
dialogues.text: “My dear solicitor, my dear friend, After much thought, I’ve changed my mind about the measures concerning my finances related to you in my last letter. I accept my father’s inheritance and ask you to wire 3,000 dollars to the Project Bank in San Francisco. Finally, I will not be in Washington until next year. I send you my friendship and I shake your hand. Yours, John Morris.” John Morris joins Warm, sitting on the ground, drawing in of his notebooks. Morris looks at him for a moment. He ha him the notebook, we can see an intricate drawing mixing letter W and M.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: It’s us. W & M, Warm and Morris. Our company’s insignia. What do you think? He smiles and hands him back the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: The brothers walk through Mayfield. The town is just as d and muddy. On either side of Main Street, families wander among tent and wagons. All the signs bear the name Mayfield: Mayfiel Supplies, Mayfield General Store, Mayfield Gold...  41.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You think this man came here because it’s called Mayfield or they started calling that once he got there?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Maybe it all belongs to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: They sure like that name. Charlie heads for the saloon. Eli follows as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: INT SALOON MAYFIELD SUNSET
dialogues.text: The saloon is crowded. The Sisters are at the bar. The bartender comes. Charlie goes to speak to him, but suddenly feels exhausted and gives up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (to the barman) Hello, we're looking for a man named Warm. Short, dark skinned... We think he passed through here a few days ago.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I can’t help you, mister. He starts to leave but Charlie grabs onto his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No ? What about a tall brown haired man of forty...

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, mister. I don’t get mixed up in it

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Oh You don’t get mixed up in it do you?” Give us some whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Normal or Mayfield‘s?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Normal. Bottle, two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: You're looking for someone?  42. A deep voice. Charlie turns to face Mayfield, a middle-ag woman with a magnetic gaze and a tough look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Because usually I’m the one people ask for news in this town.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Mayfield. Charlie turns around to his brother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ah! The great man himself! Behind them, the bartender puts the bottle down and pours them drinks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My brother and I are looking for a man named Hermann Warm. Short, dark skinned? Probably passed through fiveor six days ago?

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Warm?... No, I don’t recall. Charlie finishes his glass, making a noise with his tongu From the one shot, he is already feeling happier.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Is this man a friend of yours? Eli starts to answer but Charlie beats him to it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He ran out on a debt to our employer, The Commodore, in Oregon City. Charlie watches for an effect. And the woman has tensed t hear the Commodore’s name.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We are the Sisters brothers. And to his satisfaction, Mayfield is duly unsettled. Eli, the other hand, is put off by this braggadocio.  43.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Good to meet you men. You planning on staying long? Eli stares at his teeth, chomping at his cigar. Charlie t around and looks at the clientele. A group of girls is co down a staircase. His shoulders straighten up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well that depends...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (sternly) We'll be leaving first thing. Charlie drains his glass. His eyes are glazed from booze.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL STAIRCASE EVENING
dialogues.text: The hotel is dilapidated, the staircase narrow. Eli and Charlie carry their bags up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Why the hell you keep telling everyone your life story? The Commodore, the Sisters brothers...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you see how honored that woman was to put us up? And besides, I like to know if our reputation has preceded us. Unlike you, brother, I’m proud of what I do. Eli sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It means it’s going to be the same as usual: you'll drink like a fish tonight and be sick as a dog tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're forgetting something: I’m going to fuck like a rabbit!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Another day up our ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie runs Charlie runs up the stairs. We hear women’s laughter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t pay attention to him, he’s crabby, he’s old!

dialogues.speaker: INT SALOON MAYFIELD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie sits at a table, drinking. He has a cheap whore o his lap, and his hand under another one’s skirt. She gigg into his shoulder. Eli is at the bar, embarrassed. He looks away. Mayfield i bit farther off, in discussion with a group of trappers. Behind them, Eli notices a girl by the piano. They exchan glances. Mayfield waves to the barman, who brings another bottle.S comes over and starts to pour Charlie a drink. Eli’s hand stops her.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: He can pour his own liquor.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Sure thing!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey look who’s awake? Look at that. Big knife with the big boy. Where are you going?! Hey have you noticed how many raccoons there are in this town? Like dead raccoons? It’s a shitty town to be a raccoon in! Mayfield puts the bottle back down.Eli goes over to the g near the piano. She forces a smile. He whispers into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How much just to talk?

dialogues.speaker: INT ROOM MAYFIELD NIGHT
dialogues.text: They are sitting on the bed in a narrow room. Far apart. Hands in their laps. A moment of embarrassment.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: We can act like you’re giving me this shawl and you consider it a valuable object. You understand? With a kind word. She takes the shawl and tries to think of something to sa She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Here. Eli gives it back, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No. With a kind, huh....

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What... I don’t know what...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Simple words: « I thought it might get cold...»

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I thought...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I’m leaving and you're giving me this.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I... I thought it might get cold... He encourages her to improvise but she just repeats what said, handing him the shawl.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This shawl...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: “,..is a little piece of me that’s traveling with you.”

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This shawl is a little piece of me...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (frustrated) You have to... with your eyes, you have to look at it! Like it means something.  46. The woman obeys, and speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This shawl is like a little part of me is traveling with you... I puta drop of my perfume on it.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (softer) Good. Now, can I steal a kiss from you? She closes her eyes to get kissed.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, you say that. Eli’s lips touch hers. She takes his hand and suddenly tu away.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Are you not well? No answer. He sees a tear roll down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Did I hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: No, not at all... you’re just very kind and gentle, and I’m not used to it. Please let me go.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: But... I’1l pay. He grabs onto her arm.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I need to go, please. She runs to the door, starts to open it, turns back aroun

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: About what? The woman mouths something, pointing down. Eli reads her lips: “May-field!”  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli has gathered their belongings. He walks around the gallery of the saloon, hugging the walls. Down below, in dark corner, he sees Mayfield speaking with a group of suspicious-looking trappers. He climbs the stairs, passes by some whores in a hallway. pushes open a door, then another. He sees men on top of women, women straddling men.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Charlie..? Charlie...? Another door... Eli finds Charlie slumped on a sofa, in a narrow red cabi from which a half-dressed whore exits quickly. Charlie, almost passed-out, is slumped on a sofa.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: There you are! Charlie. Charlie! You have to wake up. They’re coming. You get up!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You get up! Mom says, Get up! Get up!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ok...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Put your boots on. Come on. Hey, Charlie, Charlie. Can you shoot, can you shoot? Eli puts Charlie’s boots on. Charlie’s head wobbles, with stupid grin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not at my best...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Don’t you puke on me. The brothers reach the stables.  Charlie finishes getting dressed as best he can, while readies the horses as quick as he can. When a voice surprises them:

dialogues.speaker: HEAD TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Getting ready to leave Mayfield? Eli stops dead. The four trappers are there. 48. Eli Eli looks at Charlie, hung over, his head burrowed in his horse’s mane. He turns to the trappers:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s just calm down. We have money. Just tell us what Mayfield is paying you.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD TRAPPER
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’re going to live long enough to find that out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s funny that there’s so many few words to describe things here in Mayfield. Charlie, who was out of it till now, slowly lets go of Ni and seems to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mayfield’s whiskey and Mayfield’s hotel, Mayfield’s Fucking Mayfield...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Please let me handle this. Look...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mayfield’s racoon, Mayfield’s Horses... Eli is worried to see Charlie wobbling.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just tell us how much you want?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, Eli, it’s not about money... it’s about reputation. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Being the guys that killed the Sisters brothers. Eli sees that something has changed in his brother’s eyes feels reassured.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD TRAPPER
dialogues.text: You shut up now.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Prestige. Charlie throws up. A beat. The trappers look at him in disgust. And in a flash, the brothers draw simultaneously. Their cylinders spin, their barrels spit fire, flames light up barn... Three trappers go flying into the hay... The four runs out of the barn and tries to escape... Charlie whistles to Eli, who tosses him another gun, with even glancing at him... Charlie catches it and, at the same time, aims and fires. 63 INT MAYFIELD’S OFFICE NIGHT: Mayfield speaks expressionlessly. A rivulet of blood runs down from her forehead and drips off the tip of her nose.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: ... Warm said he needed an investor for some prospecting scheme. I couldn’t make heads or tails of his story. I thought he was a clown, but when I saw Morris, I thought... if the Commodore’s interested, it might be worthwhile.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did Morris leave a letter for us?

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: No. He was just traveling with Warm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Really? And why did you want to kill us?  50. Mayfield hesitates. Charlie raises the butt of his revolv

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'll repeat that, then I’1l strike.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: When I realized Warm had something of value, I sent some guys after them to bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: So now there’s more men on Warm’s tail?

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: Yes. Charlie raises the butt of his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All right, Mayfield, you’re not going to like what comes next, but it’s the price to pay when you mess for messing with our buisness. Open your safe. Mayfield’s face freezes. She slowly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAYFIELD
dialogues.text: No. Never.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 64 INT. MAYFIELD’S OFFICE NIGHT: Later. Charlie is emptying a safe: bills, pieces of gold, pouche gold dust. The office has been turned upside down. Mayfield’s body l in the middle, in a puddle of blood.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT MAYFIELD SALOON NIGHT
dialogues.text: Loaded down with their plunder, they see half the town outside, awoken by the gunfight.A group of poor people, s in nightclothes.  51.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (softly) Think we should say something to them? The silent crowd separates to let them through. Charlie l at the curious townspeople, then up at Eli.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: After a series of dramatic events that she only had herself to blame for... Mayfield is dead!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, not like that. Don’t you have anything more positive? Charlie mounts Nimble.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My brother and I have some good news for you people! You can change the name of your fucking town! They spur their horses and gallop away. Behind them, a cr of famished people invades the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: 66A EXT LOOT FOREST DAWN
dialogues.text: Their saddlebags, knapsacks and pockets are stuffed with bills, coins and gold dust. The horses gallop.

dialogues.speaker: 66B EXT LOOT FOREST DAY
dialogues.text: Fifty yards off the trail, on a hillside, the brothers fi digging a hole behind trees and rocks.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Anyway, now we know one thing for sure. We know Morris has joined the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I never liked that gentleman, but I must say this is the icing on the cake.  52.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Warm have that’s so interesting? The Commodore sends men after him, Mayfield sends men after him, and now Morris falls into him. What does he have?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He has a formula. It’s a chemical product. Supposedly, you pour it in the river, it lights up all the gold, and you just bend down to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You don’t believe that stuff Charlie, come on! We’ve seen our fair share of hucksters with miracle products...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes but the Commodore seemed to believe in this one.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me about it before?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I had orders not to. In the hole, they put their treasures, wrapped in oilskin

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Anything else you’re hiding from me? Charlie looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Commodore’s orders are clear- cut: before we kill Warm, we are to extract from him by whatever violent means necessary the recipe for his formula.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: In lay terms: torture him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: More or less.
The brothers ride side by side, through plains and rivers

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How far ahead do you think Mayfield’s guys got?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well if they’re as stupid as the last guys we killed, I'd say we're about even.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I like it here. There’s a fortuitous energy.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What the hell is a “fortuitous energy”?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You feel it, dummy!

dialogues.speaker: EXT CLIFF DAY
dialogues.text: The path is climbing up through short vegetation.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know what, brother? I don’t think you and I have ever gone so far.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You mean between us, in our conversation?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? I meant in a straight line. You and I have never gone so far in a straight line! The brothers can hear a distant, continuous rumbling. All a sudden, here is it, wide and endless: the ocean. They put their hands on their hats so they won't fly and at the water. It’s obvious they’ve never seen something l it.  54.

dialogues.speaker: 70A EXT PACIFIC BEACH DAY
dialogues.text: At times, waves come crash on the horses’ hooves. The brothers ride through the beach. There’s no one to be see for miles and miles.

dialogues.speaker: 70B EXT PACIFIC BEACH EVENING
dialogues.text: There are prints on the sand now - men, animals, carriage and sometimes a few objects people have left on the way: trunks, furniture, a bed...

dialogues.speaker: _ EXT STREET SAN FRANCISCO NIGHT
dialogues.text: They ride up a street on horseback, into the fray: tents up in the lanes, trappers, chained slaves, Chinese famili sleeping in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (eyes glittering, almost moved) Goddamn, this place is Babylon! When they look up, they can see three-floor brick houses brightly-lit windows.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You know, when we find Warm, it won't be worth looking for a quiet spot, there isn’t one in this whole place!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: More importantly nobody will care. We can kill anyone we want here. Fuck, everyone’s mind is focused on something else.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET SAN FRANCISCO NIGHT
dialogues.text: Elsewhere. They leave their saddles at a stable and continue on foot their gear propped on their shoulders. In front of them, they suddenly spot a warm and hospitabl light, the lights of a “grand hotel”, The Golden Pearl.  55. They look inside through a window. Like two kids in front a Christmas window display.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL GOLDEN PEARL NIGHT
dialogues.text: A valet precedes them through an upstairs corridor with a kerosene lamp. He points to a door:

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: That’s the water-closet in there... ++. and then another door...

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: ..-that’s the bathroom, with hot water. «.. and yet another door.

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: And here is your room. He opens the door, enters and begins to turn on the lamps The room appears: a red velvet bijou, gold tassels, braid pompoms, beds in rococo copper... They've never seen anything like it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red as a lobster and wrapped in a towel, Eli has just ste out of a hot bath. He looks curiously at the dangling cha with a wood knob. He hesitates, pulls on it, and to his surprise a torrent of water gushes into the toilet bowl.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Charlie, come and look at this! He walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A restaurant in the same style as the rooms: European overkill. The two brothers have no clue how to behave, or what to d with all the silverware set before them.
Eli and Charlie are eating and drinking. Especially Charl

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A bit of comfort in uncertain times. Eli nods. A Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You know I was thinking... We could just go back to Oregon City and say we couldn’t find them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And tell what to the Commodore?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The truth: Morris ran off with Warm. Destination unknown. Can’t be expected to find them without a single clue to guide us. And... (lower) We don’t even know if Mayfield’s men have already found them...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ok, what are you getting at, brother? Eli lowers his voice and starts in:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Between what we made in Mayfield, what we have at home and the rest, we have enough to ditch the Commodore for good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And why would we do that?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever think of stopping?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I don’t know (he hesitates) We could open a store together.  57.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What store?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Look, we've had a good long run, we're still alive, we’ve a bit of our youth left. It’s a chance to get out. Charlie turns beet-red. Alcohol mixed with pent-up anger.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A store? A way out? Fucking nonsense! What is this bullshit? He is about to knock over the table or slap Eli who stare him without backing down.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ...Well, we’ve established that you want to quit, so quit! Charlie finishes his glass and takes a deep breath. He st eating again. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Meaning what? That if I stop, you’d continue?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Of course I’d continue. I'd just need a new partner. Rex asked for work in the past...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Rex? Rex is just a talking dog.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He is obedient like a dog. I could ask Sanchez. Eli is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Sanchez...? You would really trust Sanchez and that idiot Rex to protect you? Charlie looks him eye to eye.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because you protect me? Is that what you have to tell yourself to stay “nice guy Eli”? But WE are the Sisters brothers. The Sisters brothers, Eli you and me! Charlie straightens up and starts searching his pockets f money.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You've made your decision, and it’s fine by me. It will be welcome news to he Commodore also. We'll finish this job, then part ways. He throws a few bills on the table. Moved, Eli pays no attention and continues.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Why do you say it like that? "We'll part ways"?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How do you want me to say it? If I stay with the Commodore and you open your store...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: So you're saying we won’t see each other any more?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, when I come into town. Whenever I need a shirt, or some underthings... Eli watches Charlie light a cigar and stand up as if noth were the matter.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Do you need to speak to me so rudely? To choose those words? To keep the level of the conversation so low. Is it because you're drunk? Charlie looks at his brother and slaps him. Instinctively, Eli’s hand grips the butt of his revolver. Customers around them freeze and watch Charlie put on his and leave the restaurant with the face and gait of a drun man.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fully clothed, Eli is lying on the bed in the dark, gaudy room. He stares at the shadows from the street played out red velvet walls and the ceiling. Charlie’s bags and clothes are still sitting on his bed. Eli stands up and starts packing.

dialogues.speaker: 77_INT STABLE DAY
dialogues.text: Eli is about to mount Tub when:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Hey, brother! He turns around. Charlie is all rosy and dapper.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Eli is speechless. Charlie continues, matter-of-factly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I've got some great fucking news, brother. I know where they are! What do you say to that? Eli look at him without answering.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t even care? What’s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember what happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. And?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember that you hit me? Charlie pretends to try to remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop pretending and spare me the « I don‘t remember » routine. You hit me in public Charlie, so as sure as you’re looking at me right now, I’m leaving. Charlie grabs Tub’s bridle.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All right, what do you want? This is about slapping each other, isn’t it? I slap you, you slap me back and we’re even. So go on, hit me. Hit me, I said. 60. Before he can even give Eli his cheek, he receives a stun that sends him flying backwards.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ! Are you out of your goddamned mind? I gave you a slap, and you whack me with a fucking shovel!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: See? You do remember! Charlie gets back up, rubbing his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (facing camera) This morning I woke up in a whorehouse and figured I might as well stop by the claims office. So I went and asked if a certain Herman Kermitt Warm had recently staked a claim. Nothing! I was about to give up, when boom, it hit me. I asked if there was anything in the name of John Morris... and there: American River, Folson Lake... bingo! Now we know where they're heading.

dialogues.speaker: EXT AMERICAN RIVER DAY
dialogues.text: CU: a crude map of American River. Eli holds the map. He tries to find his bearings in the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride on. First, a delta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+. They ride the river upstream... They pass by men on f with mules, loaded down with gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There are now prospectors at work on each of the riverbanks. Charlie takes a pair of binoculars, peers at camps, the faces...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I'd like to see how they go about it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh another idea for a career change? First selling shirts, now prospecting? I’m gonna go on ahead, you do as you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Tub’s eye has turned white and is surrounded by pus. shoos away flies and tries to clean the wound. The horse shudders and peels.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MOUNTAIN ROADS DAY
dialogues.text: Now it’s all uphill. Tub is breathing hard. He drools spi and blood. His eye is now white, pus oozing around it. A horse of the Apocalypse.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MOUNTAIN DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie calls out to a prospector below:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Folsom Lake? The prospectors point upstream.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How far?  62.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: A day ! He rides back to Eli.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We'll be there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Encampment. Remains of a fire. Under the covers, Charlie already asleep. Eli tries to make Tub drink. He encourage him, speaking softly.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Come on Tub. Eat some grass. Oh Tub, I’m sorry my friend. Tub’s white eye almost glows in the dark. He takes the red shawl from his saddlebags. He carefully folds it into a pillow, breathes in its fragrance and goe bed. He pulls up his blanket and begins to masturbate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm binocular POV: The silhouette of the sister brother, sleeping next to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: WARM, (0.S)
dialogues.text: You think it’s them?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. They got here faster than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
