dialogues.text: The brothers are asleep. The sound of the river below, the horses. Another noise. Eli opens his eyes: a silhouette towers over him... Nearby, Charlie straightens up... the toe of a boot viole knocks him flat. Black. A blurry vision. Voices of men heard from afar:  63.

dialogues.speaker: WARM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No!.. No, not like this! Warm joins Morris.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Not like what?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: This is no way to kill people.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: We have to kill them, Hermann! We kill them, bury them, no one finds them. By the time it dawns on the Commodore, we’ll be far gone.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We don’t work for the Commodore anymore!

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing here? Warm and Morris turn around. Eli, in a daze, has stood up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: We...We don’t work for him anymore. 82 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY Charlie and Eli ground. Charlie Contrary to the seems strangely are handcuffed, sitting together on the has a nasty black and blue mark on his cheek. specifics of their current situation, Charlie happy:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And it just came out?!?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: ~-. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're a genius, Eli, a goddamn genius! How did that pop into your head? Just out of the blue? He nods, evasively. Warm and Morris have set up camp on a wide strip of pebbles in the middle of the river.  64. Two tents, some gear, barrels, oilskin tarpaulins protect their supplies. The horses are tied up on the banks. They watch Warm and Morris gather the gear they need, loa the animals. Charlie yells at them:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Morris, what you gonna do with us? Ask us to run and shoot us like rabbits? Dump us in the forest? Charlie sniggers, Morris barely looks back. 83 INT MORRIS’S TENT DAY: Morris is sitting at a small wood table, studying a map. walks into the tent, Morris doesn’t turn around.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: What are we going to do about them?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: We leave them here. They’1l end up killing each other or getting eaten alive... I couldn’t care less. We take the horses and the mules, we extract what we can from the river one last time and then we leave here without ever coming back.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: And abandon all our gear?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: We'll travel light, ride up to Sacramento, buy more gear, and ride up the river from there. Suddenly, from further down the hill:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (OS)
dialogues.text: Anyone there? 84 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anyone there? Can you hear me? Morris takes a few steps forward.  65.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, what do you want? Another silhouette appears in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're working the river downstream. We’re running out of supplies. You’ve got any for sale? Warm joins Morris.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: They don’t look like prospectors.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: They’re not prospectors.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear your answer.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (To the man) Because I didn’t give one. Don’t you take one step closer! (to Warm) We're going to have to fight, Hermann. Are your guns loaded?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so. The silhouettes are creeping closer.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Well take it out goddammit ! (to the man) I told you not to move and I won’t tell you again! We have nothing to sell. Go back to where you came from! The man comes towards them. Morris shoots. The others sho right back. Flames, ricocheting bullets. Behind them, the brothers shield themselves as best they can.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, what the hell? Do something! Don’t leave us here! A bullet ricochets near Warm, who jumps away.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Hermann! Hermann?  66.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) I’m okay, I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Let us help you, Warm! Another volley of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Give us the keys you fucking idiots! You don’t stand a fucking chance, come on! Warm and Morris look at each other. They hesitate. 85 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY: The four men are hiding behind boulders. The brothers che the weapons that have been returned to them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You think it’s Mayfield’s men?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Sure looks like them. Charlie signals Warm and Morris to stop shooting. He stan up, using his hands as a megaphone:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey guys, before things sour, we've got some news for you: Mayfield is dead! You'll never get paid! Do you think this is really worth it? A beat, as if a discussion were going on over there. Then more gunfire. Charlie makes his way to Warm and Morris, b busy shooting.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (To Morris and Warm) As long as you can see us, you shoot at them like crazy. We make it to the other side and you can’t see us anymore, stop shooting. Get it? Agreement.  67. The brothers come out of hiding and move along, each to o side of the river. Warm and Morris fire. When the brother vanish into the forest, they stop shooting. Suddenly, the sounds of long 45 caliber flames pierce the day. We hear screams... then nothing. Eli reappears, dragging his feet, as if coming back from chore. Whena trapper arises from behind a thicket. Morris cocks revolver and shoots in a hurry. The trapper collapses revealing Charlie, his arm outstretched, his gun still smoking. The two men face each other. Frozen. And then slowly lowe their arms. A moment of unease. 86 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT NIGHT: They sit around the fire in heavy silence. They pass arou jug of liquor. Sizing one another up, eyeing one other. Eli notices that John Morris is scratching his legs. Hermann Warm clears his throat, then:

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: If Morris agrees to it, this is what I suggest. You two keep half of what you pull from the river, with the remaining half going to the Company.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Company being you and Morris?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Yes, well, no... not exactly. The Company is our phalanstery project.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Phalan-what?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Phalanstery...

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: .--A community we’re founding, in Texas. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WARM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An ideal living space, ruled by the laws of true democracy and sharing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Does something bother you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's your business.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: So we agree: half of what you extract?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Me too. His eyes turn to Morris.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Excellent. Morris? After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Don’t ask my opinion. I don’t agree with what’s going on here. I’m still in, of course, but I remain on my guard.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you look at me when you say that? Morris gets up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Look at me, you son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Morris turns to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m looking at you, Charlie Sisters. Do you want me to tell you what I see?  69.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: That’s enough! Eli holds back Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Please... The tension decrease.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Do your legs still hurt?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m all right. Goodnight, Hermann. They watch him wander off towards one of the tents.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He going to have to change. Warm gives a resigned shrug of the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: He doesn’t trust you and you can’t blame him. He’ll change. We all have to. We don’t have any other choice. His eyes are on them, a clear gaze, frank and disarmingly innocent. He scratches his legs nervously. Under the bott of his pants, the brothers make out red skin that is star to blister.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: It's the Formula. It is very caustic in its purest form. I thought diluting it would make it harmless, but I was wrong. Next time, we'll have to grease our skins beforehand... He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Have you already prospected?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Two days ago.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Better than I ever imagined. He walks away. 87 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY: Early morning. Eli washes at the river. A little further he sees Morris brushing his teeth. He waves. Morris barel reacts. Off to one side, Charlie sits on the river bank, watches from afar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses, men and loaded mules make their way along the mountainside. Warm and Morris check the river’s flow. The brothers follow, pulling the mules. Charlie still wea the trapper’s hat. Ahead of them, Warm points to the river below. They come closer and discover a spot where the current sl down and the river bed widens. A landscape like before th birth of the world. 89 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY : They cut the branches on a tree they just felled. A mule pulls a trunk into the middle of the river. Bare-chested, the men cut branches and carry rocks... The work up to their waists in water. The dam is starting to take shape. Warm crosses the damme river to gauge its depth. With a knife, he scrapes the boulders in certain spots. He examines the samples with a jeweler's magnifying glass. Very tight shot: striations in the rock, shimmers of quar golden reflections.  71.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER BANK
dialogues.text: The sun is beating down. The men nap in the shade of the trees. Just the sound of insects and the river.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ENCAMPMENT EVENING
dialogues.text: A new camp has been set up below at the foot of one of th riverbanks. Eli and Charlie finish setting up tents when they hear hoofbeats. They look back. Warm and Morris arrive with a straining under three barrels. The brothers watch the con pass by: it is obviously the Formula. Eli sees his brother’s eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER BANK ENCAMPMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: All four sit around a fire to finish their supper.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Who wants to stand guard tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s our job, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER BANK NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wearing his trapper's hat, Charlie sits up on a rock that towers over the river. After a while, he hears laughter down in the valley. He straightens up and sees the three others drinking and laughing, gathered around the fire. .

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: We can’t sleep!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s the point of me being on guard, if you all don’t go to sleep?  72.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Charlie, why don’t you come down and join us? It’1ll do you good.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on, there’s no point. We're not going to sleep !

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER BANK NEW ENCAMPMENT DAWN
dialogues.text: The four of them have their feet in the water. They guzzl booze. They rarely speak,smoking cigarettes and watching sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER DAM DAY
dialogues.text: Morris is swimming in the translucent river. Charlie sits the riverbank, mocking look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you really believe in that two- bit ideal society nonsense?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know but I say that a guy with a little bit of smarts has to realize that it sounds like solid gold bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Why do you think I’m here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like us. For the gold.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Sure, the gold, but what do you do with it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Spend it, obviously!

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You really think you'll have time to? With all the corpses you've left behind, the Commodore, your famous drunkenness... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if your pockets are full to boot, something tells me you won't be living to a ripe old age.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And would your ideal society make a difference?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I can’t say for you, but for me, yes. Charlie thinks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Or else it’s a scam. A trap for suckers. Is that it?... Morris gestures that he has heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, John Morris: you are one goddamned arrogant asshole.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Charlie Sisters: I couldn’t care less about what you think... that is to say, if you think.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP DAY
dialogues.text: Eli goes to check the horses. They are all there, except Tub. A piece of old rope dangles where he had been attach Eli whistles, looks everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST TUB HOLE DAY
dialogues.text: He notices some blood on a bush. More, a little further on. Then hoof prints on the ground...He reaches the edge of a landslide. At the bottom of the ravine, Tub, motionless on his back, hoofs up. Eli looks at him, saddened.
Eli is sitting on the riverbank, looking at the reflectio the sun in water, at the jumping trout.

dialogues.speaker: WARM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Eli turns around to see Warm coming towards him.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Nothing much.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: I’m heading up to the dam to see if the water has settled.

dialogues.speaker: 98B EXT RIVER BANK DAY
dialogues.text: They are walking. At the bend, they see the dam where Mor and Charlie are working and talking.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: See that?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I get the impression Charlie is changing...

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You mean he’s not going to try to kill us anymore?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It’s a little strange talking about this with you, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: It’s Better facing up to things. You know, one day I asked Morris how he ended up working for aman like the Commodore. He said something along the lines of... the desire to break away from his family, to live an adventure. Honest enough. How about you? How did you end up here? Eli smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Does my question bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s just a long story. Charlie was always violent. When he got into a fight, it usually would end badly. And when you kill a man, you end up with his father, his brother or his friends on your tail, and you have to start all over again. One thing leads to another and I had to help him. He’s my brother. 75. They walk in silence. At one point, Eli makes a face. He his hand to his heart. He is dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: You all right? Eli shakes his head. His hand looks for something to against. Warm helps him.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Must be the heat. We’ll sit here a moment and it will pass.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... I lost my horse... He died, I mean... Tub is dead... He was a middling horse, but... I didn’t think it to affect me like this...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: When we were kids, Charlie killed our father. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I’m the older one. I should have done it.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Do you regret that?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes...‘cause after that, Charlie was never the same. lean  76.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RIVER CAMP DAY
dialogues.text: Morning. Charlie sits on a rock, bare-chested. Eli is cut his hair. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That was a very pleasant day, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You get on well with Warm?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And you with Morris?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What did you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: About us, about the Commodore... About Pa. He’s an easy man to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Tell me, what do you think the Commodore will do when he sees we're not coming back?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’1ll send men after us. We’1ll have to get rid of them. And the ones after, and all the others he sends on our trail.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And then, sooner or later, to put an end to it, we’ll have to kill the Commodore... Eli does a double take. He considers the possibility.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Imagine we manage to kill the Commodore. What next? Charlie doesn’t answer. Eli hesitates, then:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You take his place?  77.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Are you taking the Commodore's place? Charlie looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How long have you been thinking about it? Charlie smiles, giving a small, mysterious shrug of the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: 100A EXT RIVER DAM NIGHT
dialogues.text: They cover their legs with grease, they pour the solution into smaller buckets. Warm and Morris exchange a look of hope. Warm looks straight to the lens. The smile on his face is hard to read: an ambiguous mixture of worry and excitemen

dialogues.speaker: 100B EXT RIVER DAM NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the moonlight, the dammed up water looks like a black mirror. Charlie and Eli are on the riverbank, next to one of the barrels. Morris is standing on the top of the beavers’ da with a long branch. Warm, also with a branch, is standing the other side of the river.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Once you’ve emptied the solution, Morris and I will agitate the water to increase the field of illumination. Now once the formula starts to activate, grab your buckets and get to work! Not a moment to lose. Charlie and Eli lift the barrel and enter the water. They pour out the dense, viscous formula. The odor disgusts th Warm and Morris hurry to stir the water with their branch dispersing the solution. Charlie and Eli retreat to the riverbank, coughing.  78. They whack their branches on the water even harder, until Warm motions them to stop. The brothers wait on the bank. Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Warm?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Just wait. The four men stare at the black water, waiting. Suddenly, a glow, then another, then... the river lights The four men rush in with their buckets: Warm and Morris under the dam, Charlie and Eli on the other side. Innumerable tiny gold nuggets, now dots of light, as clea stars in the sky. The four men work the river as fast as they can. All we c hear is the clanking of the nuggets falling into the buck The leafy trees look like a vault of gold overhead. Eli stops a moment to watch the three men working. Their faces are lit by the river. They all smile. A breeze play with their hair. Eli smiles too and goes back to work. Then the glow dies down as quickly as it appeared. Slowly the leafy vault darkens. Eli heads back to the bank, crying and coughing. He sees Charlie banging away at the cover of another barrel.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We'll dump it all in! Warm sees him from the other bank.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Leave off! Eli, stop him! Charlie lifts the barrel. He takes a few steps. He loses balance and falls. Thick liquid pours out of the barrel a trickles onto his right hand, immediately attacking his s The loose barrel rolls down to the river, where the formu spreads in viscous filaments.  79. Blisters appear on Charlie’s forearm. They swell and pop a toad’s throat. He holds back a shriek of pain.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Charlie? Behind him, the river shines again in the barrel’s wake. Morris and Warm run across the dam. Morris trips. Eli see him fall into the water and disappear. He holds his breat Morris’s face resurfaces. He screams. Eli sees Warm put down his bucket and immediately darts u

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, Hermann, no! But Warm jumps in and disappears, like Morris.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER DAM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The water is black. Warm resurfaces, holding up Morris. T cough, spit, gasp for breath. They collapse onto the sand 101B EXT WARM’S CAMP DAWN: Day breaks slowly over a landscape that has lost its colo Dead beavers and fish wash up onto the gravel. On the riverbank, Morris is dying. A groan more painful than the others makes him turn his h Morris is looking at him. His face is horribly burnt, his lips quiver as if trying to speak. Charlie knows what he is begging for. He stands up and fi a belt with weapons. He grabs one as best he can with his left-hand fingers that still work. He tosses the revolver to Morris, and then kicks it close his hand. 102A INT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli goes inside Warm’s tent. Face ravaged by blisters. Milky eyes bulging out. Heavy breathing.  80.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hermann? Can I do something for you?

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Morris? Is that you? Eli starts to clarify, but...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s me.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: Oh, John! Where did you disappear to?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I was getting some firewood.

dialogues.speaker: WARM
dialogues.text: John, I feel I have known you a long time. I’m sorry you died before me. I wanted to help you. I wanted to be your friend.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You are my friend, Hermann. Warm retches. His last sigh sounds like paper crumpling. As Eli inches closer to Warm, a gunshot rings out. Eli st straight. 102B EXT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY: Eli comes out of the tent. Charlie looks at him. By his side, Morris, dead, holding the revolver against h chest. 103 EXT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY: Eli packs their bags to leave. He brings the results of t night’s collection: a bucket two-thirds full of nuggets. He manages to fit their treasure into Warm and Morris’ horse’s saddlebags. Charlie is too weak and ill. He stays under the covers.  81. 104 INT MORRIS’ TENT. DAY: Eli gathers Morris' things. On a crate by the bed, he discovers a hardback notebook w a title on its cover: "Adventure diary". The pages are blackened with cramped, regular writing. El feels a presence behind him. He leaves the tent.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I must confess that the very happiest moments of my life have been spent in the wilderness of the far west with the plentiful supply of dry pine logs on the fire. I would not... I would sit cross legged enjoying the genial warmth and watch the blue smoke as it curled upwards.

dialogues.speaker: 105A EXT MOUNTAINS. CALIFORNIA DAY
dialogues.text: The brothers walk down the river.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Scarcely did I ever wish to change such hours of freedom for all the luxuries of civilized life.

dialogues.speaker: 105B EXT MOUNTAINS. CALIFORNIA DAY
dialogues.text: In the steep passes, Eli has to tie Charlie to his back. ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli hears a scream from behind. Charlie has fallen from h horse. Eli rushes over. 107 EXT CRANE’S TOWN DAY: There are houses at the end of the road. 108A INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY A black forearm falls to the floor with a thud. Eli picks up and places it in the bucket nearby.  82. Doctor Crane cauterizes and bandages the stump. Charlie is still asleep on the operating table. Eli looks at the stump in the bucket. 108B INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fly lands on Charlie’s mouth. Eli chases it away, wipes brother’s brow. Eli sits back down. Behind him, the doctor is washing his hands. Noise in the vestibule. The doctor’s little girl has come home. Father and daughter speak in hushed tones. Then father and little girl enter the room. Doctor Crane looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there are men asking about you.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the street. Three of them. Eli lifts the curtain and looks across the street. There silhouette in front of the saloon/ general store. The guy is not trying to hide. He nods, swaggering. He lo like a killer. Eli cautiously opens the door a chink.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Rex, shit !

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Eli?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Is it true that Charlie is out of the game?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What do you want?  83.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Me? Nothing. The Commodore sent me. It’s been a while since you left and he’s growing impatient. Eli peers into the street and sees two other silhouettes behind him. When he looks back, he sees Charlie on the ta

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (to the doctor) Is there a back door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Go, go, go, go, go! Charlie, Charlie get up ! We have to go. Eli is about to lift Charlie to carry him. Charlie opens eyes and uses his good arm to grasp Eli’s collar. Eli doe not understand. Charlie hangs on. Stares into his eyes, without letting u His stare is tantamount to an order. He shakes his head in an irrevocable “no”. Eli puts him back down. Charlie’s eyes remain glued to hi

dialogues.speaker: REX, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do I have to come in and get you?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, I’m coming out!

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: First you toss your guns, then come out with your hands up! Eli goes to look for Charlie’s Colts. He slips them into back of his pants and undoes his belt.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET DAY
dialogues.text: He opens the door, tosses his belt and raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Good. Come on out and talk! Seen from behind, the butts of Charlie’s Colts stick up i his pants.  84. 110 INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie lies on the operating table. His eyes are open. H hears voices. When the first gun goes off, his stump goes to draw. Bullets shatter a window pane. The doctor and his daughte crouch. 111 EXT CRANE’S TOWN STREET DAY: Two men lie sprawled across the street. One of them screa in pain. Eli steps over and shoots him in the head. The third man crawls to take shelter. Rex. Eli walks towa him, crushes his back with his boot.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Are there others behind you? Before Rex answers, Eli fires.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST MAYFIELD DAY
dialogues.text: The brothers gallop on Rex’s horses, new boots and spurs their feet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FOREST MAYFIELD DAY
dialogues.text: They try to find their buried treasure. But the mountain shifted and the spot is unrecognizable. Charlie finally finds the fork in the tree and tries to l up with it. All he can see are the disheveled fir trees, a box of matches spilled on a table.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s go. Charlie looks around. Distraught.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROCKY LANDSCAPE EVENING
dialogues.text: The sound of a cavalcade approaching. A group of horsemen gallops by. Hidden by the rocks, Eli watches them ride by. When he ca longer hear them, he comes out of his hiding place, pulli his horse by his tether.  85. Charlie leans over the horse’s neck to grab the reins wit his good hand. He puts the reins in his left hand, spurs the horse and passes in front. Eli follows him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT LANDSCAPE GUNFIGHT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darkness. Flashes of light and muted gunfire in the distance. We mo in slowly. CUT TO. Sheltered behind the trunks of felled trees, Eli shoots i the shadows. The shadows shoot back. Crouched next to him, Charlie reloads guns as best he can with a bad hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The horses! Get the horses to safety! Charlie makes the horses lie down and lies down alongside them. Charlie’s face against the horse’s side. He closes his eyes. For the first time, he is afraid. FADE TO...

dialogues.speaker: 116A EXT PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: A wide, flat landscape. On one end, the two brothers gall followed on the other end by four men who start shooting them. In the distance, gunshots and smoke. FADE TO...

dialogues.speaker: 116B EXT PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: Two men lie on the ground, dead. One of them has his foot still caught in his horse’s stirrup. Charlie searches the bodies, grabs their weapons and ammo, and hands them to E who's still on his horse. FADE TO...  86.

dialogues.speaker: 116C EXT PRAIRIE DAY
dialogues.text: Galloping again. The horses’ immaculate white coat. FADE TO...

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROCKY LANDSCAPE NIGHT
dialogues.text: They have built a fire. Charlie cries. Eli changes his brothers bandage wrapped u around bloody stump. woe oe As he stands guard and finishes eating, Eli discreetly watches him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Rex and Sanchez, and those other guys we didn’t even know... You really think it’s a good idea to go back up north?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Well you know very well why were going north. And you know what we still have left to do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I lost the hand that I work with. You'll be on your own on this. Charlie lets go of the powder flask. Eli wants to help immediately, but stays where he is. Charlie has seen that keeps trying. Eli can’t look at his brother struggling with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you ashamed of me? Charlie’s eyes well with tears.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Do you mean what your saying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Everything has fucking changed so much.  87.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, nothing has changed. You’re my little brother and I love you. Eli empties his pan in the fire. It sizzles and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: In a week, we'll be in Oregon City, and I‘1l kill the Commodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is lying asleep near the embers. Eli stands guard He hears his brother's sobs getting lost in the stillness the night.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANDSCAPE DAY
dialogues.text: The sun is beating down. The two brothers are riding slowly. At one point, Eli sto around: empty landscape as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hey, have you noticed how long it’s been since anyone’s tried to kill us?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know... three, four days ?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Don’t you find that strange? Charlie turns around now. He also finds it strange. 119: INT/ EXT BARN OREGON CITY DAY. Final rehearsal. Charlie repeats one last time.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You walk in the front door. Take the staircase on the right, go up make a left, the office is on the second door on the left.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: How many guys are up there with him usually?  88.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Usually there’s a guy sitting right outside the office. And one in the room further down. They load their guns. 120 EXT COMMODORE’S MANSION OREGON CITY- DAY: With his remaining hand, still damaged, Charlie slips a g in his belt. The brothers enter the town, which is strangely deserted. They walk up the street. In the distance, a black cloth h been striated around the large door of the Commodore's mansion. People scurry about underneath, as if waiting for somethi 121 INT. COMMODORE’S MANSION OREGON CITY- DAY: The Sisters brothers are standing side by side in a wood- paneled parlor. Eli takes off his hat. Charlie follows suit. Behind them, townsfolk dressed in black, sitting on two r of benches. In front of them: an open coffin. Inside, the Commodore's corpse, lying on ice. An undertaker is standing nearby, waiting to hammer the l on.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (softly) Fuck! You must be disappointed. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yeah, kinda.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Sir? I think no one else may be coming. May we close the casket?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Sure.  89. They put on their hats and start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hold on. Eli turns around, steps back to the coffin, gun in hand, brings it slamming down on the dead man’s face. An unpleasant cracking sound. Ice cubes bounce on the woo floor. General astonishment. Eli raises his hand to calm everyon down.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Just making sure. Then they leave.

dialogues.speaker: EXT OREGON CITY DAY
dialogues.text: They gallop out of town and up to the plain. The evening falls. Their conversation continues, indistinct in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SISTERS FARM DAY
dialogues.text: The sun is about to rise. At a bend in the road, a modest farm appears: barn, stables, farmyard, fenced in vegetabl patch. As Eli and Charlie head up the slope, a woman appears in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Hey, if you come any closer I'll shoot you!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It’s us Ma’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s your sons, it’s Charlie and Eli!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: My sons? Oh my god, well why, why did you come, why did you come back?  90.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: To see you Ma’.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: If you came here to hide or to run away from something you just turn around, I don’t wanna see ya!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No we're tired Ma’. We just want to come home.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We just came here to see you. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli watches his mother’s old hand stroking Charlie’s face They speak, but he does not hear what they are saying. He walks around the house, his eyes lingering on the wall he finds the a measuring rod, marked with names and numbe Charlie, a date, a height, Eli, a date, a height. He pushes open the door to their bedroom. Their beds are there, one on each side of the room. Behind him, he hears the voices of Charlie and their moth Eli sits down, pulls off his boots, lies down on the bed, soothed by their voices. He stares at the piece of cloth over the window, gently billowing in the breeze. Lulled by its back and forth, hi eyelids grow heavy. His feet are twenty inches too long f the bed. On the floor, through the curtains’ sway, the breaking li of day. THE END.
